name: Virasoro algebra
rephrased: The Virasoro algebra is a specific type of complex Lie algebra that provides a central extension of the Witt algebra, playing a crucial role in two-dimensional conformal field theory and string theory.
implication_form: If a central extension of the Witt algebra is required for two-dimensional conformal symmetry, then the Virasoro algebra is the unique nontrivial example.
explained: The Virasoro algebra \(\mathfrak{Vir} = \mathfrak{Vir}(c)\) is a complex Lie algebra with generators \(L_n\) for \(n \in \mathbb{Z}\) and a central element \(c \in \mathbb{C}\) (the central charge). It is the universal central extension of the Witt algebra, which consists of all vector fields on the circle. The Lie bracket is defined by: \[ [L_m, L_n] = (m - n)L_{m+n} + \frac{m^3 - m}{12} \delta_{m+n,0} c \quad \text{for all integers } m, n \] where the second term is the central extension. The Witt algebra corresponds to the kernel of the central extension map. The Virasoro algebra plays a fundamental role in two-dimensional conformal field theory (CFT) and bosonic string theory.
